entry.title: Combined summary - Fwd: Proposal for a new opcode
entry.summary: In March 2012, Watson Ladd proposed a new opcode, OP_CHECKEXPSIG, for anonymous transactions to the Bitcoin community. The purpose of the opcode is to validate an opaque signature and allow for anonymity in transactions by enabling scripts to prove that the receiver has carried out a previous transaction. Ladd was working on a paper discussing the use of this opcode for anonymous transactions. However, there were some questions about how it would enable anonymous transactions as it seemed isomorphic to a hash locked transaction from the perspective of the blockchain. Ladd clarified that one cannot use this opcode alone to secure a transaction; it is meant to prevent double spend attacks against anonymization schemes. To avoid this leading to a double-spend, a quorum method is used based on showing earlier redemptions happened. When questioned why it is not isomorphic to a hash locked transaction, Ladd explained that you can't blind a Lamport signature which makes it different. Gavin Andresen expressed excitement about the proposal and requested to read the paper for further details. He also mentioned that additional work may be required beyond introducing a new opcode in order to provide strong anonymity, such as creating new transaction types that clients can understand.Ladd suggested an alternative protocol for N parties who wished to purchase equal amounts of Bitcoin without the exchange being able to link their future transactions. Each participant put up the relevant amount of gold/whatever at the exchange and provided a public key for signing. Externally, the participants agreed on a collection of non-cooperating mixers, which could be the participants themselves or independent third parties. This alternative protocol required no changes to the Bitcoin system and could be easily implemented by anyone interested. It provided anonymity so long as any one of the mixers was uncompromised. Overall, Ladd's proposal aimed to enhance anonymity in transactions through the use of a new opcode. Despite some confusion about its implementation, the idea behind the opcode showed promise for improving the security and privacy of transactions. Ladd is currently working on a paper discussing the use of this opcode for anonymous transactions and searching for a place to post it as it seems to be of interest.
